title: Team member with Program permission only can escalate to Admin permission

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
## Summary

`https://hackerone.com/TEAM/groups` URL is accessible to team members with Program permission, even when "Group Management" and "User Management" menus aren't visible.

I didn't research this further, however, I was able to grant all permissions to the user assigned to a group with `Program` permission.

## PoC

> Tested on a user assigned to a group with Program permissions

1. Go to `https://hackerone.com/TEAM/groups`
2. Select the current user's group
3. Add arbitrary permission (e.g. Admin)

## Additional information disclosure

I noticed that `hackerone.com/teams.json` is accessible to users with "read-only" permission, but `https://hackerone.com/TEAM/groups.json` is accessible to users with at least 1 valid permission. 

That's strange because the data is *identical* and **allows disclosing user ids, assigned groups, groups permissions**.

Reporting 2 issues in one report, because it's hard to understand the real root cause of the broken RBAC.

## Impact

- A team member with 1 valid permission (except "readonly", e.g. Program) can escalate own permissions in the team to arbitrary permissions.
- "readonly" team member can disclose the team's groups, assigned users, groups' permissions and ids/names.
vulnerability_information_html:
Summary

https://hackerone.com/TEAM/groups URL is accessible to team members with Program permission, even when "Group Management" and "User Management" menus aren't visible.

I didn't research this further, however, I was able to grant all permissions to the user assigned to a group with Program permission.

PoC

Tested on a user assigned to a group with Program permissions

  1. Go to https://hackerone.com/TEAM/groups
  2. Select the current user's group
  3. Add arbitrary permission (e.g. Admin)

Additional information disclosure

I noticed that hackerone.com/teams.json is accessible to users with "read-only" permission, but https://hackerone.com/TEAM/groups.json is accessible to users with at least 1 valid permission.

That's strange because the data is identical and allows disclosing user ids, assigned groups, groups permissions.

Reporting 2 issues in one report, because it's hard to understand the real root cause of the broken RBAC.

Impact

  • A team member with 1 valid permission (except "readonly", e.g. Program) can escalate own permissions in the team to arbitrary permissions.
  • "readonly" team member can disclose the team's groups, assigned users, groups' permissions and ids/names.

activities.message:
Hey @sodacan,

`/TEAM/group_management` includes info about program groups, their permissions and members.

When a "readonly" users make a request to `/teams.json`,  they receive the next data in response:

```json
[
	{
		"id": 11111,
		"handle": "XXXX",
		"url": "https://hackerone.com/XXXX",
		"profile": {
			"name": "XXXX",
			"twitter_handle": "",
			"website": "XXXX",
			"about": "XXXX"
		},
		"state": "public_mode",
		"profile_picture_urls": {
			"small": "https://profile-photos.hackerone-user-content.com/XXXX",
			"large": "https://profile-photos.hackerone-user-content.com/XXXX
		},
		"permissions": [], // <-- current user's permissions
		"review_requested_at": "DATE",
		"review_rejected_at": null,
		"has_policy?": BOOL,
		"has_avatar?": BOOL,
		"settings_link": "/TEAM/edit",
		"settings_disabled?": BOOL,
		"launch_link": "/TEAM/launch",
		"has_external_program?": BOOL,
		"number_of_whitelisted_reporters": 0,
		"offers_bounties": BOOL,
		"offers_swag": BOOL,
		"awards_miles": BOOL,
		"default_currency": "usd",
		"access_hacker_invitations": BOOL,
		"can_view_response_setup_guide": BOOL,
		"can_view_program_health": BOOL,
		"can_view_feedback_dashboard": BOOL,
		"can_view_all_weaknesses": BOOL,
		"can_edit_policy_and_scope": BOOL,
		"triage_enabled": BOOL,
		"groups": [
			{
				"id":  ID,
				"key": "h1-triage",
				"name": "H1 Triage",
				"team_members_count": 24,
				"permissions": [
					"report_management",
					"program_management",
					"reward_management",
					"user_management"
				],
				"immutable": false,
				"team_member_ids": [
					{id: 1111111}
				]
			},
		],
		"response_efficiency_indicator": "ok",
		"response_efficiency_percentage": 0
	}
]
```

Readonly users can view:
- available program's groups: names and ids
- permissions assigned to these groups
- users ids assigned to the groups

Do I need to provide any additional info?

Thanks!
activities.markdown_message:
Hey @sodacan,

/TEAM/group_management includes info about program groups, their permissions and members.

When a "readonly" users make a request to /teams.json, they receive the next data in response:

[
    {
        "id": 11111,
        "handle": "XXXX",
        "url": "https://hackerone.com/XXXX",
        "profile": {
            "name": "XXXX",
            "twitter_handle": "",
            "website": "XXXX",
            "about": "XXXX"
        },
        "state": "public_mode",
        "profile_picture_urls": {
            "small": "https://profile-photos.hackerone-user-content.com/XXXX",
            "large": "https://profile-photos.hackerone-user-content.com/XXXX
        },
        "permissions": [], // <-- current user's permissions
        "review_requested_at": "DATE",
        "review_rejected_at": null,
        "has_policy?": BOOL,
        "has_avatar?": BOOL,
        "settings_link": "/TEAM/edit",
        "settings_disabled?": BOOL,
        "launch_link": "/TEAM/launch",
        "has_external_program?": BOOL,
        "number_of_whitelisted_reporters": 0,
        "offers_bounties": BOOL,
        "offers_swag": BOOL,
        "awards_miles": BOOL,
        "default_currency": "usd",
        "access_hacker_invitations": BOOL,
        "can_view_response_setup_guide": BOOL,
        "can_view_program_health": BOOL,
        "can_view_feedback_dashboard": BOOL,
        "can_view_all_weaknesses": BOOL,
        "can_edit_policy_and_scope": BOOL,
        "triage_enabled": BOOL,
        "groups": [
            {
                "id":  ID,
                "key": "h1-triage",
                "name": "H1 Triage",
                "team_members_count": 24,
                "permissions": [
                    "report_management",
                    "program_management",
                    "reward_management",
                    "user_management"
                ],
                "immutable": false,
                "team_member_ids": [
                    {id: 1111111}
                ]
            },
        ],
        "response_efficiency_indicator": "ok",
        "response_efficiency_percentage": 0
    }
]

Readonly users can view:

  • available program's groups: names and ids
  • permissions assigned to these groups
  • users ids assigned to the groups

Do I need to provide any additional info?

Thanks!

activities.message:
After thinking for a while, I think **the impact on Confidentiality and Integrity isn't "Low"**, because this vulnerability allows elevating privileges to admin, so it's possible to:
- modify program settings,
- add and delete arbitrary program users, 
- disclosing billing info, 
- disclosing reports, posting comments, etc.
- granting arbitrary rewards
- removing groups and users from the program,
- and **doing other Admin-level things**.

It requires some privileges for exploitation, but still, it's possible.

Additionally, that information disclosure about groups/permissions/users to "readonly" users is pretty useful for further exploitation.

I can't setup a demo program (it's rate limited even after I contacted H1 support), but as I guess, accessing "Group management" is possible with any permission (Reward OR Program OR Report).
activities.markdown_message:
After thinking for a while, I think the impact on Confidentiality and Integrity isn't "Low", because this vulnerability allows elevating privileges to admin, so it's possible to:

  • modify program settings,
  • add and delete arbitrary program users,
  • disclosing billing info,
  • disclosing reports, posting comments, etc.
  • granting arbitrary rewards
  • removing groups and users from the program,
  • and doing other Admin-level things.

It requires some privileges for exploitation, but still, it's possible.

Additionally, that information disclosure about groups/permissions/users to "readonly" users is pretty useful for further exploitation.

I can't setup a demo program (it's rate limited even after I contacted H1 support), but as I guess, accessing "Group management" is possible with any permission (Reward OR Program OR Report).

That's strange because the data is identical and allows disclosing user ids, assigned groups, groups permissions.

@sodacan, more correctly:

  • https://hackerone.com/TEAM/groups.json is a "group" field of the response from https://hackerone.com/teams.json

Hi @metnew,
Thank you for providing the requested updates. H1 is reviewing the additional information and will get back to you should there be any questions or comments.
@sodacan

Hi @metnew,
I have passed along your report to the internal team. We will keep you updated with any new information as soon as it becomes available. Your patience is appreciated.
@sodacan

activities.message:
Hi @metnew - 

Thanks for the report! 

Regarding privilege escalation, I cannot reproduce and do not believe it's true that you can grant or change permissions as a read-only member. If you believe otherwise, please re-open and provide a detailed POC. 

Regarding information disclosure, it is by design that you _are able to_ view:
- The list of team member groups of your program; 
- And within each team member group, 1) the associated permissions; 2) the team member in this group (their id and usernames and total member count)

We believe that as a read-only member shall be able to access the above information. You might also notice that in the Inbox filter view, the read-only member is allowed to filter reports by "Assigned To", supplying either a team member or a team member group name. 

Let me know if this clarifies things.

Thanks,
Pei
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @metnew -

Thanks for the report!

Regarding privilege escalation, I cannot reproduce and do not believe it's true that you can grant or change permissions as a read-only member. If you believe otherwise, please re-open and provide a detailed POC.

Regarding information disclosure, it is by design that you are able to view:

  • The list of team member groups of your program;
  • And within each team member group, 1) the associated permissions; 2) the team member in this group (their id and usernames and total member count)

We believe that as a read-only member shall be able to access the above information. You might also notice that in the Inbox filter view, the read-only member is allowed to filter reports by "Assigned To", supplying either a team member or a team member group name.

Let me know if this clarifies things.

Thanks,
Pei

## PoC

1. Go to https://hackerone.com/TEAM/groups

activities.message:
@pei @sodacan **I'm sure that the vulnerability (priv esc from Program to Admin) is reproducible and it remains unpatched at least for 8 days (since the reporting date).**

> Regarding information disclosure, it is by design that you are able to view:

Regarding the information disclosure: **I think that's not a feature, it's a bug**. Because nobody except Admin should be able to disclose other permissions to prevent targeted attacks. That's obvious.

> We believe that as a read-only member shall be able to access the above information.

Yeah, I guess it's might be ok to allow readonly users:
-  to access team names/ids, 
- **possibly**, they even can access other  team members, 
- but for me it's clear that readonly users **shouldn't see others permissions**.
activities.markdown_message:
@pei @sodacan I'm sure that the vulnerability (priv esc from Program to Admin) is reproducible and it remains unpatched at least for 8 days (since the reporting date).

Regarding information disclosure, it is by design that you are able to view:

Regarding the information disclosure: I think that's not a feature, it's a bug. Because nobody except Admin should be able to disclose other permissions to prevent targeted attacks. That's obvious.

We believe that as a read-only member shall be able to access the above information.

Yeah, I guess it's might be ok to allow readonly users:

  • to access team names/ids,
  • possibly, they even can access other team members,
  • but for me it's clear that readonly users shouldn't see others permissions.

activities.message:
Hi @metnew - Thanks for clarifying! I was able to reproduce the issue:

- Sign as a team member with only program permission
- Go to `/<team_handle>/groups` through URL directly
- Edit the group you belong to, and select "Admin", and you are now granted Admin permission.

We'll escalate this ASAP. Thanks!
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @metnew - Thanks for clarifying! I was able to reproduce the issue:

  • Sign as a team member with only program permission
  • Go to /<team_handle>/groups through URL directly
  • Edit the group you belong to, and select "Admin", and you are now granted Admin permission.

We'll escalate this ASAP. Thanks!

additional_data.old_title: Team member could escalate permissions inside the program + information disclosure about groups and team members to readonly user
additional_data.new_title: Team member with Program permission only can escalate to Admin permission

activities.message:
Great, thanks, @pei.
I can't see the CVSS score. Is it triaged as `CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:H/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H`. (unchanged + high privileges requires + full CIA impact)?

Just curious, do you have any plans on hiding others' permissions from `/teams.json` for non-Admin users?
activities.markdown_message:
Great, thanks, @pei.
I can't see the CVSS score. Is it triaged as CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:H/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H. (unchanged + high privileges requires + full CIA impact)?

Just curious, do you have any plans on hiding others' permissions from /teams.json for non-Admin users?

activities.message:
Hi @metnew -

> I can't see the CVSS score. Is it triaged as CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:H/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H. (unchanged + high privileges requires + full CIA impact)?

Here's what we set for CVSS score: `CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:H/UI:N/S:U/C:L/I:H/A:N`. Though as a team we are still discussing about it, so this might change and if you have additional input please let us know! One particular case we are concerned about is regarding team member of HackerOne, because we use the team member group and permissions to manage the permissions of our internal tooling - which could potentially give them access and privilege to other programs on the platform. 

> Just curious, do you have any plans on hiding others' permissions from /teams.json for non-Admin users?

We are OK with showing the permissions of other team members to all team members.

Here's what we set for CVSS score: CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:H/UI:N/S:U/C:L/I:H/A:N. Though as a team we are still discussing about it, so this might change and if you have additional input please let us know! activities.message:
Hi @metnew -

We discussed the severity and settled on Medium. 

For an attack scenario for a non-HackerOne program, the CVSS score is set to `CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:H/UI:N/S:U/C:L/I:L/A:N/CR:H/IR:H/AR:H` - note that we set environmental scores to High for all CIA on `hackerone.com` asset.

For an attack scenario for the HackerOne program, the CVSS score is set to `CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:H/PR:H/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:N/CR:H/IR:H/AR:H` - note that CI went from "Low" to "High", but the attack complexity went from "Low" to "High" and the user interaction changed from "None" to "Required" as all of the high-risk actions in our internal tool require interaction/approval from another privileged team member.

In both scenarios the severity is determined to be Medium.

Enjoy the bounty, and thanks for the report again!
-Pei
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @metnew -

We discussed the severity and settled on Medium.

For an attack scenario for a non-HackerOne program, the CVSS score is set to CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:H/UI:N/S:U/C:L/I:L/A:N/CR:H/IR:H/AR:H - note that we set environmental scores to High for all CIA on hackerone.com asset.

For an attack scenario for the HackerOne program, the CVSS score is set to CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:H/PR:H/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:N/CR:H/IR:H/AR:H - note that CI went from "Low" to "High", but the attack complexity went from "Low" to "High" and the user interaction changed from "None" to "Required" as all of the high-risk actions in our internal tool require interaction/approval from another privileged team member.

In both scenarios the severity is determined to be Medium.

Enjoy the bounty, and thanks for the report again!
-Pei

Hi @pei and @security ,

I totally disagree with the bounty and impact.

I hope that the root cause of this misunderstanding is that H1 forgot that users with Admin permission could assign any permissions to themselves and even create new privileged users.

Users with "Program" permission have had administrative access in their programs all the time (until Jun 21 2019).

For reference:

I'm not a fan of "awarding by CVSS" bureaucracy and especially in this particular case, because this vuln has more impact than most of the disclosed H1 vulnerabilities.

Just for references, I compared impact/rewards for other vulnerabilities disclosed by H1 with this bug:

  • https://hackerone.com/reports/419896 - Unauthenticated user can upload an attachment to the last updated report draft (CVSS 8.3??! how do you estimate the impact here?)
  • https://hackerone.com/reports/423073 - same impact as in the report above (7.5K, CVSS 7.7!!)
  • https://hackerone.com/reports/386997 - Private program policy page still accessible after user left the program (2.5K, CVSS 4.2)
  • https://hackerone.com/reports/380317 - Team object exposes amount of participants in a private program to non-invited users (5K, CVSS 4.4)
  • this report - 2.5K, CVSSv3 5.7 from your estimation CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:H/PR:H/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:N/CR:H/IR:H/AR:H (which I consider pretty biased)

non-HackerOne program

You estimated this vuln for any program except hackerone.com/security as CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:H/UI:N/S:U/C:L/I:L/A:N/CR:H/IR:H/AR:H (3.8!!!)

"Scope" -> "changed"

"Scope" is "changed" (you estimated as "unchanged") - broken RBAC allows a user with "Program" permissions to edit own permissions and gain "Admin" privileges and consequently gain "Reward" and "Report" permissions for further malicious actions.

"Privileges Required" -> "Low"

  • You set "Privileges Required" to "High".
  • From my experience, "Program" permission mostly assigned to program policy managers, lawyers, team managers, and employees responsible for communications with hackers and promotions.
  • Even according to CVSSv3, "High" should be set when the user initially has "administrative" permissions. In this case, "Low" is more appropriative.

"Integrity" -> "High"

Integrity was set to "Low". Do you mean the bug only impacts the attacked team and not whole H1 or what? How is CIA estimated here?

The ability to perform actions like granting arbitrary rewards(monetary impact), untimely disclosing reports, changing APIs, changing permissions inviting new team members, should make "Integrity" set to "High".

That means CVSS score is at least 8.5 for non-H1 programs. (if "Privileges Required" set to "High", it's 7.6)

Hackerone (and "internal tooling")

From #343464 (May 2018) its publicly known that hackerone.com/security has the next team structure:

{
  "data": {
    "team": {
      "id": "Z2lkOi8vaGFja2Vyb25lL1RlYW0vMTM=",
      "name": "HackerOne",
      "handle": "security",
      "": {
        "total_count": 30
      },
      "team_member_groups": [
        {
          "id": "7506",
          "name": "Support",
          "permissions": [
            "support_mutation"
          ]
        },
        {

          ]
        },
        {

          ]
        },
        {

          ]
        },
        {

          ]
        },
        {

        },
        {

          ]
        },
        {

        {

}

You said H1 uses this RBAC for "some internal tooling".
In reality, H1 totally relies on this RBAC model.
There are many non-standard H1-only properties which cover operational things like sales/finance/hr/marketing/etc.

> List of non-standard permissions in H1 as of May 2018 
support_mutation
support_saml
support_directory
support_customer_success
support_sales
support_finance
support_marketing
support_hr
support_hacker_success
support_open_source_review
support_sql_query_analyzer

At this point, it's clear that this vulnerability affects H1 as both business and platform, not only as a platform for hacker/program communication. All aspects of HackerOne (finance/sales/HR/marketing departments) are potentially affected by this privilege escalation.

You said:

but the attack complexity went from "Low" to "High" and the user interaction changed from "None" to "Required" as all of the high-risk actions in our internal tool require interaction/approval from another privileged team member.

First of all, H1 should provide a detailed analysis of the bug for hackers and customers to demonstrate the transparency of their security. I saw in publicly disclosed reports that @jobert made such analysis (with source code) for some bugs.

  • Could you provide more info about the handling of "high-risk actions" and your RBAC model?
  • Which actions are accessible to Program and Admin users?
  • Is it possible to test your internal RBAC model on a sandboxed program?

I think at this point, it's unclear why I should trust this particular assessment.

Let me re-calculate CVSS for H1 scenario to omit any further speculations.

  • Scope -> Changed (I hope it's clear why)
  • Ok, we can calculate CVSS even with required "User Interaction". (High Privileges + User Interaction)
  • Without impact on "Availability" - 7.7, with "Availability" impact - 8.0

Audit? Response? + Summary

  1. HackerOne should make an internal audit and notify affected customers.
  2. HackerOne should provide a detailed analysis of this bug (and maybe root cause?)

I think that the assessment of this bug was incomplete and lacks in-depth analysis:

  • wrong CVSS scores and "speculative" impact estimation,
  • responses like "somewhere in our internal tooling we have some internal checks for some actions by some privileged members"

TBH I consider this bug is one of the most critical bugs among all disclosed reported to H1 vulnerabilities. I hope my point is clear.

Thanks.

P.S.

I didn't expect such a response from H1.
Is it just a miscommunication, or H1 discriminates me for some reason? It really feels like discrimination.
This report wasn't triaged for 9 days! #614800 was just closed without any explanations.

activities.message:
Hi @metnew - thanks for your reply, it's appreciated. I wanted to take a moment to elaborate on our decision. Our internal support application indeed uses HackerOne groups to assign permissions, people are granted access to it based on their membership of @security and their permissions. Our initial assumption was that people with Program Management permission could elevate themselves to an Admin, and then assign any group to themselves. This would give them more access in our Support Application. However:

* The vulnerability only allowed people to elevate their permissions within a program, **when they already had the Program Management permission**. This permission gives a user the ability to do anything, except managing the program's memberships and group memberships. We determined the likelihood of this happening to be Low.
* For HackerOne's program, seven people were identified who had this particular permission, out of which four didn't have the "Admin" permission already. The remaining four were part of other permission groups that had broad access within our Support App.
* Our Support App contains a feature that allows people to schedule arbitrary commands on production application servers. This feature requires acknowledging an additional Duo (2FA) and another member of the Engineering group to approve the request. Because we use Single Sign-on, it was **not** possible for anyone to register a second account, sign in to the Support App, and approve their own requests. None of the other features in the Support App are considered to have a High impact on Confidentiality. Due to these defenses, we determined the Attack Complexity to be High and User Interaction to be Required. This lowered the severity to a Medium.

We audited existing programs and determined that, besides you, this was not abused in any approved program (outside of our sandbox).

Because all the scenarios we played out resulted in a Medium, we opted for the severity that was least complex, didn't require user interaction, and wasn't specific to HackerOne. This scenario only had a Low impact of Confidentiality and Integrity, but still resulted in a Medium severity vulnerability. This is our final decision.

We thank you for your contributions to our program lately and we look forward to receive more security vulnerabilities from you!

Jobert

activities.message:
Hey @jobert,

First of all, I **very appreciate** your response.
It's great that you've provided such an interesting inside about internal H1 implementation.

But your response lacks explanation about other H1 programs (non-`/security`).

## non-H1 programs and CVSS

As I said, this privilege escalation allows doing many scary things like:
- disclosing reports
- rewarding hackers
- changing permissions
- etc.

And there is no option for team members to add **MFA** (like in H1) .

### CVSS

It's still not clear why H1 estimated this bug for non-H1 programs as `3.8` (!)
According to my estimates, it should be `7.6-8.5`.

Thanks.

> Yeah, I want to disclose this too. But it'd be great if you can provide an explanations about non-H1 programs at first.

non-H1 programs and CVSS

As I said, this privilege escalation allows doing many scary things like:

  • disclosing reports
  • rewarding hackers
  • changing permissions
  • etc.

And there is no option for team members to add MFA (like in H1) .

CVSS

It's still not clear why H1 estimated this bug for non-H1 programs as 3.8 (!)
According to my estimates, it should be 7.6-8.5.

Thanks.

Yeah, I want to disclose this too. But it'd be great if you can provide an explanations about non-H1 programs at first.

activities.message:
Hi @metnew - you're right that this could've also caused a program member to elevate their permissions to Admin, and then assign Reward Management or Report Management. We do believe that the impact on Integrity is still Low though, because it only affects one program and the user would've required significant permissions to do so. For it to have a High impact on Integrity, one would have to find a security vulnerability that shows a significant impact outside of the user's program or reports.

Happy hacking!
activities.markdown_message:

For it to have a High impact on Integrity, one would have to find a security vulnerability that shows a significant impact outside of the user's program or reports.

Happy hacking!

activities.message:
Hey @jobert,

Thanks again for your response!
Sorry, but I really want to follow up on this. 
> Sorry, if it consumes much of your time.

1. But it makes sense to notice that Scope of this bug is changed
2. `High impact on Integrity` - according to CVSSv3, High impact could be set in cases, when the impact on the affected components is valuable enough. For example, assuming the Program user could elevate priveleges to "Admin", they could **force disclosure of all reports in the program**. Such an impact should be considered severe for both H1 (as a business) and the program. Another example of severe impact is monetary impact.

Thanks.

activities.message:
Hi @metnew - no worries, happy to elaborate.

> "Scope" of this bug is "changed"

Can you explain how this affects another system? The Support App is the same code base as hackerone.com. It's a Rails Engine that is mounted on `/support` when a particular environment variable is set. We run a number of application servers, of only a few have that flag set and are only accessible through our VPN. I don't think that this affects other systems outside of https://hackerone.com / https://hackerone.com/support.

> High impact on Integrity

Unfortunately, it's subjective. We decided that when it only affects a single program, we consider the impact on the integrity of our data to be Low. We're sure that there are exceptions to this rule, but we haven't seen them yet.

Have a good day!

We run a number of application servers, of only a few have that flag set and are only accessible through our VPN. I don't think that this affects other systems outside of https://hackerone.com / https://hackerone.com/support.

High impact on Integrity

Unfortunately, it's subjective. We decided that when it only affects a single program, we consider the impact on the integrity of our data to be Low. We're sure that there are exceptions to this rule, but we haven't seen them yet.

Have a good day!

activities.message:
Hi @jobert,

Thanks again for the reply! I hope that will be the last message.

I understand that the threat model of H1 is something similar to "storage of **private** security issues". 
Probably, it's correct to say that one of the main goals of H1 as a platform is to provide private communication between programs and researchers.

I think I was able to find a way to explain how this vulnerability could impact other systems.

### Business/legal/Intellectual impact for program/H1/researchers

1. <Privilege escalation>
2. Attacker **discloses all reports publicly**. That's a very impactful thing for programs like Dropbox/Github (which don't disclose reports until a request from the reporter) and programs which disallow public disclosure. 
3. The potential impact for the program (company) may vary. It'll definitely lead to business inquiries from customers, "impact on the brand" in news, probably something bad will happen with the program's compliance.
4. From another side, public disclosure breaks the confidentiality of finders' researches. That's obviously **impactful for reporters**, which often don't want to disclose and share their techniques.
4. The fact that confidentiality of customer's (and finders') reports was violated (publicly!) should reflect HackerOne as a business too. And probably it may violate ToS.
5. Note that, if the attacker discloses reports as "readonly" user via "export" feature, there will be no evidence that these reports are actually leaked. And H1 isn't responsible in this case, the program is. **Any user could export reports, but not anyone could disclose them**.

#### TL;DR: 

0. <PrivEsc> -> Full public disclosure of all reports.
1. H1 as a platform doesn't behave in this case as "private storage of the reports and researches"
2. Business impact for the company: compliance/business customers/news/legal.
3. Finders' intellectual property violation: techniques and researches are publicly accessible.
4. Attackers achieved this impact via a vulnerability in HackerOne. 
5. All the reports are publicly accessible on the main page (`/hacktivity`) of Hackerone!
6. HackerOne is definitely responsible here and it's likely H1 will suffer from the **legal impact.**
7. Huge scandalous.

### Triagers deanonymization
On "Managed" programs, groups admins (only users with **Admin** permission) can see triagers' emails. H1 triagers' emails have a form of "<name>@managed.hackerone.com" or "<first_letter_of_the_name><lastname>@managed.hackerone.com". Also, admins see emails of all other members of their team.

 I don't have access to "Enterprise plan", but "custom integrations" and "hierarchical programs" sound very interesting to search for an additional impact. Some integrations even in the "Professional" plan could be **bidirectional**.

> Initially, I considered RBAC as a (vulnerable) component, a vulnerability in which allows members with "Program" permission to run actions of "Reward/Admin/Report" groups. So if my assumption is correct, "Scope" of the bug is "changed", assuming a program is a self-contained system. However, considering a single program **only** as a part of H1 platform, I would agree with your statement (except for integrations/hierar.


> TBH I strongly believe that this vulnerability is much more impactful compared to vulnerabilities like "some component allows uploading attachments to draft reports".
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @jobert,

Thanks again for the reply! I hope that will be the last message.

I understand that the threat model of H1 is something similar to "storage of private security issues".
Probably, it's correct to say that one of the main goals of H1 as a platform is to provide private communication between programs and researchers.

I think I was able to find a way to explain how this vulnerability could impact other systems.

Business/legal/Intellectual impact for program/H1/researchers

  1. <Privilege escalation>
  2. Attacker discloses all reports publicly. That's a very impactful thing for programs like Dropbox/Github (which don't disclose reports until a request from the reporter) and programs which disallow public disclosure.
  3. The potential impact for the program (company) may vary. It'll definitely lead to business inquiries from customers, "impact on the brand" in news, probably something bad will happen with the program's compliance.
  4. From another side, public disclosure breaks the confidentiality of finders' researches. That's obviously impactful for reporters, which often don't want to disclose and share their techniques.
  5. The fact that confidentiality of customer's (and finders') reports was violated (publicly!) should reflect HackerOne as a business too. And probably it may violate ToS.
  6. Note that, if the attacker discloses reports as "readonly" user via "export" feature, there will be no evidence that these reports are actually leaked. And H1 isn't responsible in this case, the program is. Any user could export reports, but not anyone could disclose them.

TL;DR:

  1. <PrivEsc> -> Full public disclosure of all reports.
  2. H1 as a platform doesn't behave in this case as "private storage of the reports and researches"
  3. Business impact for the company: compliance/business customers/news/legal.
  4. Finders' intellectual property violation: techniques and researches are publicly accessible.
  5. Attackers achieved this impact via a vulnerability in HackerOne.
  6. All the reports are publicly accessible on the main page (/hacktivity) of Hackerone!
  7. HackerOne is definitely responsible here and it's likely H1 will suffer from the legal impact.
  8. Huge scandalous.

Triagers deanonymization

On "Managed" programs, groups admins (only users with Admin permission) can see triagers' emails. H1 triagers' emails have a form of "<name>@managed.hackerone.com" or "<first_letter_of_the_name><lastname>@managed.hackerone.com". Also, admins see emails of all other members of their team.

I don't have access to "Enterprise plan", but "custom integrations" and "hierarchical programs" sound very interesting to search for an additional impact. Some integrations even in the "Professional" plan could be bidirectional.

Initially, I considered RBAC as a (vulnerable) component, a vulnerability in which allows members with "Program" permission to run actions of "Reward/Admin/Report" groups. So if my assumption is correct, "Scope" of the bug is "changed", assuming a program is a self-contained system. However, considering a single program only as a part of H1 platform, I would agree with your statement (except for integrations/hierar.

TBH I strongly believe that this vulnerability is much more impactful compared to vulnerabilities like "some component allows uploading attachments to draft reports".

activities.message: Hi @metnew - if you believe you have found a new security vulnerability, or would like to discuss it, I'd like to ask you to file a separate report. This report has been scheduled for disclosure already and I'd like to avoid that we'd have to go back a number of times to redact information that doesn't relate to the initial vulnerability. Thanks for your understanding!
activities.markdown_message: Hi @metnew - if you believe you have found a new security vulnerability, or would like to discuss it, I'd like to ask you to file a separate report. This report has been scheduled for disclosure already and I'd like to avoid that we'd have to go back a number of times to redact information that doesn't relate to the initial vulnerability. Thanks for your understanding!

summaries.content:
Hi hackers,

**Bug**: Program members with **"Program"** permission can escalate to **"Admin"** and consequently gain **"Reward" and "Report"** permissions.

- Detailed analysis with possible exploitation scenarios and some additional impact of this bug could be found [here](https://hackerone.com/reports/605720#activity-5174796) and [here](https://hackerone.com/reports/605720#activity-5199532)
- H1 also revealed a lot of info about internal implementation in this report
summaries.content_html:
Hi hackers,

Bug: Program members with "Program" permission can escalate to "Admin" and consequently gain "Reward" and "Report" permissions.

  • Detailed analysis with possible exploitation scenarios and some additional impact of this bug could be found here and here
  • H1 also revealed a lot of info about internal implementation in this report
